ðŸš¨ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ FRAUD INVESTIGATION SPREADS TO WASHINGTON STATE: DAYCARE WITH 7 KIDS RECEIVED $81,000 IN ONE MONTH

Minnesota. Ohio. Now Washington.

Citizen journalist Cam Higby uncovered what appears to be the same playbook operating in Washington State.

Amira Child Care LLC, owned by Ahmed Amira and listed as Somali-speaking, donated $1,000 cash in 2021 to Shukri Olow, a Somali-born candidate for King County Council and Washington State House.

That donation triggered a Public Disclosure Commission investigation.

PDC Case #96266 alleged Olow's campaign accepted contributions exceeding statutory limits. 

The case was closed with a "reminder" after Olow refunded the over-limit portions. 

The PDC noted she was a "first-time candidate." 

The timing and amount, $1,000 in 2021, align with the reported violations.

Now follow the money:

2021-2023: Ahmed Amira Abdi received $383,000 in grants from the Department of Children, Youth and Families.

2023-2025: Amira Child Care LLC received $363,000.

July-November 2025 alone: $355,000. 

December not yet reported.

The math doesn't add up.

Licensed capacity: 12 children. 

Currently enrolled: 7 children.

September 2025 payment: $81,263. 

That's $11,600 per child for one month.

Higby's conclusion: 

"What it appears to be is a child care organization owned by a Somali person donating to Somali political candidates with taxpayer dollars."

Three states. Same pattern. Massive subsidies. 

How deep does this go?

Source: @camhigby / Washington PDC Case #96266

ðŸš¨ðŸ‡ºðŸ‡¸ NICK SHIRLEY: CARTEL SMUGGLING DIDN'T DISAPPEAR WHEN BORDER OPENED, IT JUST CHANGED HANDS

The government started doing what the cartels used to charge for.

Nick Shirley shared what he learned from a former cartel member about how migrant smuggling transformed when the border effectively opened during the Biden administration.

The old system:

"Before all this open border stuff happened, they would smuggle the migrants through secret entry points. 

From there they'd pay a fee to be taken to another city. 

They'd have cartel members here in the United States take them to a safe house, and then the safe house people would help them get on a bus to like New York City or something like that."

What changed wasn't the destination. 

It was who ran the operation.

Under open border policies, the secret crossings became official processing centers. 

The paid transport became taxpayer-funded flights and buses. 

The cartel safe houses became NGO shelters. 

The final destination? Still New York City.

Migrants still paid cartels to get to the border. 

But once they cross, American taxpayers picked up the tab for everything the cartels used to charge for on this side.

Source: @juliandorey @nickshirleyy

result.text:
Starlink is beginning a significant reconfiguration of its satellite constellation focused on increasing space safety. Â We are lowering all @Starlink satellites orbiting at ~550 km to ~480 km (~4400 satellites) over the course of 2026. Â The shell lowering is being tightly coordinated with other operators, regulators, and USSPACECOM.Â 

Lowering the satellites results in condensing Starlink orbits, and will increase space safety in several ways. Â As solar mininum approaches, atmospheric density decreases which means the ballistic decay time at any given altitude increases - lowering will mean a >80% reduction in ballistic decay time in solar minimum, or 4+ years reduced to a few months. Â Correspondingly, the number of debris objects and planned satellite constellations is significantly lower below 500 km, reducing the aggregate likelihood of collision. Â 

Starlink satellites have extremely high reliability, with only 2 dead satellites in its fleet of over 9000 operational satellites. Â Nevertheless, if a satellite does fail on orbit, we want it to deorbit as quickly as possible. Â These actions will further improve the safety of the constellation, particularly with difficult to control risks such as uncoordinated maneuvers and launches by other satellite operators.

result.text:
Going Positive & Going First

"This is the absolute key to life: going positive and going first. 

Don't wait for the world to be good to you. You go first. 

Be the one who goes positive first. The world will mirror back."

- Peter Kaufman

Peter Kaufman was a close friend of Charlie Munger & author of "Poor Charlie's Almanack"

This came out of his unbelievably good lecture on "Multidisciplinary Thinking"

This is one of the most impactful lectures that I've ever come across in terms of practical wisdom that I apply to my daily life

1. Mirrored reciprocation
2. Einstein's 5 levels of cognitive prowess
3. Compound interest unlocked thru constancy
4. The $8 crystal ball
5. 22 second course in leadership

the content is ASTOUNDINGLY good 

(but the lecture is audio-only & 44 minutes, most probably won't slog thru, so I created  4min video summary below thanks to YouTube transcript => Opus 4.5 => Google Slides => Google's new Convert To Video feature)

and here's the full text - I can't recommend this highly enough

Happy New Year

===
Peter Kaufman: The Multidisciplinary Approach to Thinking

Introduction:
Thank you. Hi there, everybody. Thank you for coming. Today we've got Mr. Peter Kaufman, CEO of Glenair. He wrote this book, Poor Charlie's Almanack, with Charlie Munger. It's an excellent bookâ€”the best book I've ever read in my whole life. And he serves on the board of Daily Journal with Mr. Charlie Munger, and he's going to give us a few words today. So please welcome Mr. Peter Kaufman, everybody.

Peter Kaufman:
Thank you. I'm happy to talk about any subject. I was asked to talk about the multidisciplinary approach to thinking, so I'll start out with that. If you guys get bored or something and say, "Well, I thought we were supposed to have fun listening to this today," you can raise your hand and say, "Could you talk about leadership or team building? Business strategy or ethics or something else?"

I gave a talk recently at Googleâ€”in fact, I've given three talks at Google. And the first talk I gave, they said, "What are you going to talk about?" I said, "What do you want me to talk about?" "Whatever you want. What are you usually talking about?" "I usually talk about leadership, culture, team-building, strategy, ethics."

So they said, "We don't want to hear about the team-building crap. We get that all the time. We want to hear about self-improvement." So I will mix in with our multidisciplinary topic a little bit of self-improvement as well. Is that okay?

Why Multidisciplinary Thinking?
Okay, so why is it important to be a multidisciplinary thinker? The answer comes from the Austrian philosopher Ludwig Wittgenstein, who said, "To understand is to know what to do." Could there be anything that sounds simpler than that? And yet it's a genius line. To understand is to know what to do.

How many mistakes do you make when you understand something? You don't make any mistakes. Where do mistakes come from? They come from blind spots, lack of understanding. Why do you need to be multidisciplinary in your thinking? Because, as the Japanese proverb says, "A frog in a well knows nothing of the mighty ocean." You may know everything there is to know about your specialty, your silo, your well. But how are you going to make any good decisions in lifeâ€”in the complex systems of life, the dynamic system of lifeâ€”if all you know is one well?

My Learning Method
So I tried to learn what Munger calls the big ideas from all the different disciplines. And right up front, I want to tell you what my trick was. Because if you try to do it the way he did it, you don't have enough time in your life to do it. It's impossible, because the fields are too big, the books are too thick.

So my trick to learn the big ideas of science and biology, et cetera, was I found this science magazine called Discover Magazine. Show of hands, anybody here ever heard of Discover Magazine? Okay. And I found that this magazine, every month, had a really good interview with somebody from some aspect of science. Every month, and it was six or seven pages long. It was all in layperson's terms. The person who was trying to get their ideas across would do so using good stories, clear language. And they would never fail to get all their big ideas into the interview. I mean, if you're given a chance to be interviewed by Discover Magazine and your field is nanoparticles or something, aren't you going to try your very best to get all the good ideas into the interview? With the best stories, et cetera? Okay.

So I discovered that on the internet there were 12 years of Discover magazines available in the archives. So I printed out 12 years times 12 months of these interviewsâ€”144 of these interviews. And I put them in these big three-ring binders. And for the next six months, I went to the coffee shop for an hour or two every morning, and I read these. And I read them index fund style, which means I read them all. I didn't pick and choose. "This is the universe. I'm going to own the whole universe." I read every single one.

Now, I will tell you that out of 144, if I'd have been selecting my reading material, I probably would have read about 14 of them. And the other 130, I would never in a million years read six pages on nanoparticles. Guess what I had at the end of six months? I had inside my head every single big idea from every single domain of science and biology. It only took me six months. And it wasn't that hard because it was written in layperson's terms.

And really, what did I really get? Just like an index fund, I captured all the parabolic ideas that no one else has. And why doesn't anybody else have these ideas? Because who in the world would read an interview on nanoparticles? And yet, that's where I got my best ideas. I would read some arcane subject, and oh my God, I saw it. "That's exactly how this works over here in biology," or "That's exactly how this works over here in human nature."

You have to know all these big ideas, or there is an alternative: find somebody who did what I did and just get all the ideas from them.

The Three Buckets Framework
Now, when I was your age and I was in school, I thought the asymmetry of it was very unfair because I had to do all the work. So every time I go back and meet with a group of students, I change the asymmetry over. I did all the work for you. I have 30 examples in here of models that I derived from what I call my three buckets.

Okay, so this is how I use ideas that no one else in the world uses, and yet I can be comfortable that they're right. A statistician's best friend is what? A large, relevant sample size. And why? Because a principle derived from a large, relevant sample size can't be wrong, can it? The only way it could be wrong is if the sample size is too small or the sample itself is not relevant.

So I want to tell you what my three buckets are, where I derive my multidisciplinary models:

Bucket number one is 13.7 billion years in size. Is that a large sample? It's the largest one in the whole universe. There is no larger sample. Because what is it? It's the inorganic universe: physics, geology. Anything that's not living goes in my bucket number one. 13.7 billion years.

Bucket number two is 3.5 billion years in size. It's biology on the planet Earth. Is that a big sample size? Is it relevant? Absolutely. We're biological creatures.

Let me ask you this: inorganic, bucket number oneâ€”is it relevant? We live in it. So bucket number one, we live in: 13.7 billion years. Bucket number two is what we're part of: biology, 3.5 billion years. And bucket number three is 20,000 years of recorded human history. That's the most relevant of all. That's our story. That's who we are.

Example: Newton's Third Law and Reciprocity
Okay, so we're going to take a couple of examples here of multidisciplinary thinking. We'll ask this question: Is there a simple two-word description that accurately describes how everything in the world works? That would be very useful, wouldn't it, if you could know how everything works in just two words?

So we go to bucket number one. How does everything work? We go to Newton's third law of motion. We're getting very multidisciplinary here. Does anybody in the room know what Newton's third law of motion says?

Yes, sir. "For every action, there will always be an equal and opposite reaction."

See, he wins one of my pens here for answering that question correctly. I always give out rewards. It's like operant conditioning from psychology, right? Thank you, sir. There you go. Appreciate it.

Okay. Yes, if I put this bottle of water on this table, Newton's third law of motion says that the bottle pushes down on the table with force X, and it also strangely says that the table pushes back with equal force X. That's very strange. But you know how long that's been true? 13.7 billion years, that's for sure.

Now, what if I push down twice as hard? What does the table do? What if I push down 21 and a half times harder? What does the table do? It matches. Isn't that interesting?

So we've derived from bucket number one a very simple model of how the world works. Two words: mirrored reciprocation. The world mirrors back at you how you are. If I'm good to you, you'll be good to me. If I push on you, you push back on me. It's this beautiful mirrored reciprocation.

Applying This to Human Nature
Now, when you go to bucket number threeâ€”20,000 years of human historyâ€”if you read all of the Greek philosophers, read all the religious texts, read all the great essayists, guess what they all basically said? In a hundred different ways: the world mirrors back at you how you are. If you're a good person, it'll be good to you. If you're a bad person, it'll be bad to you.

Some people call this karma. Some people call it the Golden Rule: "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you." It's mirrored reciprocation. It's Newton's third law applied to human behavior.

But here's where it gets interesting. Do you realize this works even in the short run? Let me give you an example. Let's say you're the kind of person where, when you walk into a room of people, you're a little bit anxious, a little bit worried: "I hope they like me. I hope they approve of me. I hope they think I'm smart enough, rich enough, good-looking enough." You're pushing out anxiety and insecurity. What does the world do? Mirrors back anxiety and insecurity.

But what if you flip it? What if you walk into that room and you go, "I really hope I like them. I hope they're interesting. I hope I can learn something from them. I hope I can find out what they need so I can help them." Now you're pushing out curiosity, openness, positivity. What does the world give you back? Curiosity, openness, positivity.

Going Positive and Going First
This is the absolute key to life: going positive and going first. Don't wait for the world to be good to you. You go first. Be the one who goes positive first. The world will mirror back.

Now, there's a problem with this. The problem is that it doesn't work 100% of the time. It probably works about 98% of the time. But 2% of the people you encounter are going to screw you. They're going to take advantage of your goodness. They're going to be jerks.

And what do most people do when they figure this out? They say, "Well, I'm not going to be vulnerable to that 2%." So they put up walls. They become defensive. They become cynical. And in protecting themselves from that 2%, they also wall themselves off from the 98% of wonderful people out there.

The 98/2 Rule
So here's what I do: I accept the 2%. I know 2% of people are going to take advantage of me, and I'm okay with that. Because I'm not willing to miss out on the 98%. This is the key to having a joyful life.

Lou Brock, who set the major league record for stolen bases with the St. Louis Cardinals many years ago, once said, "Show me a man who's afraid of appearing foolish, and I'll show you a man you can beat every time." And if you're getting beat in life, chances are it's because you're afraid of appearing foolish.

So what do I do with my life? I risk the 2%.

I was so proud the other day. I was reading Bono on Bono. Bono's the lead singer of U2. He's the only other person I've ever encountered in my entire lifeâ€”and I asked all my cronies, "Has anybody else ever encountered this elevator model before?"â€”and they said, "No, that's yours, Peter." And I said, "You know, I use 98/2. Guess who's got the exact same model?" Bono! When he doesn't have 98/2, he's got 90/10. Those are his numbers: 90/10. I read this and I go, "Can I be wrong on this?" That guy is really squared away. I hope someday I'm as squared away as he is. It's incredible to think he figured it out. That's why that guy's had such a great life.

He goes, "You know, I know 10% of the people are going to screw me. That's okay. If I'm not willing to be vulnerable and expose myself to that 10%, I'm going to miss the other 90%." Does that make sense?

Living a Win-Win Life
Now, Charlie Munger one day turned my whole life upside down. I was over at his house one day. "Peter, I've been hearing about you going around giving all these talks. You don't have to go around the country telling people how to make more money."

"Well, that's not what I do, Charlie." Very nimble on my feet, I said, "There's a catch. I do tell them how to make more money, but the way I tell themâ€”if they do these things that get people all in and whatnotâ€”we'll make all the money there is to be made." He really did. "That's not why I'm here. I'm here to give you the second half of the message: you just have to be a good person."

What's your name? Albert. Albert, how many lifetimes do you have? One. That's correct.

The most important thing, absolutely. Now what do we know in economics? It's an economics model. What do we know we need to use as our decision-making prism whenever something is both finiteâ€”like oneâ€”and importantâ€”like your life? How do we have to make decisions?

Opportunity cost. Have you all heard of opportunity cost? It's the classic illustration of opportunity cost. You've got a finite number of options. It's important. If you're doing A with it, it means what? It means you're not doing B, C, D, or E. What do you have to do? You have to evaluate all the different alternatives and pick the one that's most optimal. Is that fair?

So you've got one lifetime. How do you want to spend your one lifetime? Do you want to spend your one lifetime, like most people do, fighting with everybody around you? No. I just told you how to avoid that. And in exchange, you have what? A celebratory life instead of an antagonistic fighting life. All you have to do is go positive, go first, and be patient enough.

We're going to have to be patient for a week with this puppy. You know how long it usually takes for a human being to do all the probing and testing? To find out that you're for real? It takes six months. This is why nobody does it. "No, it takes too long." Compared to what? Look at the plan B that everybody uses. It's terrible. It doesn't work. They spend their whole lives fighting with everybody.

Win-Win in Business & Life
The three hallmarks of a great investment are superior returns, low risk, and long duration. The whole world concentrates on category one. But if you're a leader of any merit at all, you should be treating these three as what? Priorities. How do you get low risk and long duration? Win-win.

This is the biggest blind spot in business. People are actually proud of win-lose relationships. "Yeah, we really beat the crap out of our suppliers." "You know, we got these employeesâ€”we got them on an H1B visa. They can't work anywhere else for three years." They're proud of it. Total win-lose.

You take game theory and you insert the word "lose" into any scenario in game theory, and what do you have? Suboptimal outcomes. What happens if you insert "win-win" in any game theory scenario? What do you get? Optimal. Every time.

Understanding Others to Achieve Win-Win
What must you necessarily do if you're interested in achieving win-win frameworks with your important counterparties in life? You must understand the basic axiom of clinical psychology, which I know because I'm multidisciplinaryâ€”I also learned psychology.

The basic axiom of clinical psychology reads: "If you could see the world the way I see it, you'd understand why I behave the way I do." That's pretty good.

Now there are two corollaries to that, and I say if you buy the axiom, which you should, you must buy the two corollaries as well, because they're logical extensions. They're undeniable.

Corollary number one: If that axiom is true and you want to understand the way someone's behaving, you must see the world as they see it.

Corollary number two: If you want to change a human being's behavior, and you accept that axiom, you must necessarily, to get them to change, change how they see the world.

Now, this sounds impossible. It's not really that hard. You take a business. Most employees at a business see the world as employees. What if you could get them to see the world instead through the eyes of an owner? Do you think that's going to change how they behave? It totally changes how they behave. Employees don't care about waste; owners do. Employees don't self-police a place. This is the secret to leadership.

The Six Counterparty Groups
The secret to leadership is to see through the eyes of all six important counterparty groups and make sure that everything you do is structured in such a way to be win-win with them.

So here are the six:
â€¢ Your customers
â€¢ Your suppliers
â€¢ Your employees
â€¢ Your owners
â€¢ Your regulators
â€¢ The communities you operate in

And if you can truly see through the eyes of all six of these counterparty groups and understand their needs, their aspirations, their insecurities, and their time horizon, how many blind spots do you have? Zero. How many mistakes are you going to make? None. Makes sense.

People don't think this is possible. It's really easy. To understand is to know what to do.

Closing Thoughts
So I'm going to wrap up here. I've only got like two minutes.

There's this great African proverb. It's the definition of win-win: "If you want to go quickly, go alone. If you want to go far, go together."

Live your life to go far together. Don't live it to go quickly alone. Most people grow up wanting to go quickly alone. It doesn't work. You wind up like Ebenezer Scrooge in A Christmas Carol. You get to the end of your life. Yeah, you're rich, you're powerful, you're famous, and you want a do-over, because you realize at the end of your life, "I didn't live my life right. I don't have what really matters."

What really matters is to have people pay attention to you, listen to you, respect you, know you matter, and love youâ€”and have it be genuine, not bought. Does that make sense?

And I'll leave you with my last bit of wisdom. There's another proverb, a Turkish proverb: "No road is long with good company."

The essence of life is to surround yourself, as continuously as you can, with good company like I have today. You're marvelous company. But how did I get that? I had to earn it, didn't I? I'm not just some guy you picked off the street. I earned the privilege of coming here and the privilege of being with you. It gives me meaning in my life, makes me feel I matter, and people are listening to me. This is my strategy for getting those five things.

You can develop your own strategy, and I hope it involves going positive and going first.

Thank you.

legacy.full_text:
Going Positive & Going First

"This is the absolute key to life: going positive and going first. 

Don't wait for the world to be good to you. You go first. 

Be the one who goes positive first. The world will mirror back."

- Peter Kaufman

legacy.description: Human thought runs in a fixed order - Recognition comes first. John 10 - BBQ Principle.

result.text:
The resurrection only makes sense inside the sequence.

recognize -> interpret -> respond

The women at the tomb didnâ€™t start with a theory, they recognized the empty tomb. They recognized the risen Christ, only after that came interpretation.

Every witness follows the same order, see first, understand second, respond third.

If you break the sequence, the entire event turns into speculation, but if you keep the order, the resurrection stands on the same ground as every other act of human knowing, recognition first.

Thatâ€™s why the earliest Christians didnâ€™t argue from abstraction, they argued from what they recognized.
